head.title: Standard and exotic interpretations of the atmospheric neutrino data

article.h1: Standard and exotic interpretations of the atmospheric neutrino data

span.span:
Report on the work done in collaboration with M.C. Gonzalez-Garcia and J.W.F. Valle. Dipartimento di Fisica Teorica, Università di Torino and INFN, Sezione di Torino, via P. Giuria 1, 10125 Torino, Italy
Instituto de Física Corpuscular – C.S.I.C., Departamento de Física Teòrica, Universitat de València, E-46100 Burjassot, València, Spain
fornengo@to.infn.it, fornengo@flamenco.ific.uv.es

div.p: The present status of some theoretical interpretations of the atmospheric neutrino deficit is briefly discussed. Specifically, we show the results for the FC mechanism and for the standard oscillation hypothesis, both in the active and in the sterile channels. All these mechanisms are able to fit the present data to a good statistical level. Among them, the νμ→ντ→subscript𝜈𝜇subscript𝜈𝜏italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:to italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{\mu}\to\nu_{\tau} oscillation is certainly the best explanation to the atmospheric neutrino deficit, providing a remarkably good agreement with the data.

When cosmic rays collide with nuclei in the upper atmosphere, they produce neutrino fluxes, which have been detected by several detectors over many years [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]. Even though the absolute fluxes of atmospheric neutrinos are largely uncertain, the expected ratio R⁢(μ/e)𝑅𝜇𝑒italic-R OPEN:( italic-mu MULOP:divide italic-e CLOSE:)R(\mu/e) of the muon neutrino flux over the electron neutrino flux is robust, since it largely cancels out the uncertainties associated with the absolute fluxes. This ratio has been calculated [10] with an uncertainty of less than 5% over energies varying from 0.1 GeV to 100 GeV. Since the calculated ratio does not match the observations, we believe to be facing an anomaly which can be ascribed to non–standard neutrino properties.

Super-Kamiokande high statistics observations [1, 2] indicate that the deficit in the total ratio R⁢(μ/e)𝑅𝜇𝑒italic-R OPEN:( italic-mu MULOP:divide italic-e CLOSE:)R(\mu/e) is due to the number of neutrinos reaching the detector at large zenith angles. The e𝑒italic-ee-like events do not present any compelling evidence of a zenith-angle dependent suppression while the μ𝜇italic-mu\mu-like event rates are substantially suppressed at large zenith angles.

figure.figcaption:
Figure 2: Oscillation solution to the atmospheric neutrino problem. Allowed regions for sin2⁡(2⁢θ)superscript22𝜃TRIGFUNCTION:sine POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-theta CLOSE:)\sin^{2}(2	heta) and Δ⁢m2Δsuperscript𝑚2Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta m^{2} obtained from the global fits to all the available atmospheric neutrino data [1-9]. The three panels refer to the three oscillation channels: νμ→ντ→subscript𝜈𝜇subscript𝜈𝜏italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:rightarrow italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{\mu}ightarrow
u_{	au} (left), νμ→νs→subscript𝜈𝜇subscript𝜈𝑠italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:rightarrow italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{\mu}ightarrow
u_{s} with negative Δ⁢m2Δsuperscript𝑚2Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta m^{2} (center), and νμ→νs→subscript𝜈𝜇subscript𝜈𝑠italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:rightarrow italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{\mu}ightarrow
u_{s} with positive Δ⁢m2Δsuperscript𝑚2Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta m^{2} (right). The best-fit point for each case is indicated by a star. The shaded areas refer to 90% C.L. while the contours stand for 95% and 99% C.L. On the same plot, expected sensitivities for K2K and MINOS are also reported.

div.p:
A simplest explanation for these features comes from the hypothesis of neutrino masses and neutrino flavour oscillations, where a νμsubscript𝜈𝜇italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{\mu} transforms during propagation into a ντsubscript𝜈𝜏italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{	au} or, alternatively, a sterile neutrino νssubscript𝜈𝑠italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{s}. However, alternative (“exotic”) interpretations to the atmospheric neutrino deficit have been proposed. Among others, flavour changing (FC) neutrino interactions in matter, neutrino decay, violation of relativity principles or violation of the CPT symmetry (see Ref.[11, 12] for relevant references).

In this paper, together with presenting the most updated results for the “standard” solution in terms of neutrino oscillations, we will also discuss the status of the FC hypothesis. For the latter case, we will perform the analysis of the latest 52 kton-yrs Super-Kamiokande data [1], while in the case of the oscillation mechanism we will report on our global fit to all the available atmospheric neutrino data [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]. More detailed discussions can be found in Ref.[11] for the FC hypothesis and in Ref.[12] for the oscillation mechanism. We refer to these papers also for a more exhaustive set of references. Here we briefly recall that we calculate the expected number of μ𝜇italic-mu\mu-like and e𝑒italic-ee-like contained events as Nμ=Nμ⁢μ+Ne⁢μsubscript𝑁𝜇subscript𝑁𝜇𝜇subscript𝑁𝑒𝜇italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{\mu}=N_{\mu\mu}+N_{e\mu} and Ne=Ne⁢e+Nμ⁢esubscript𝑁𝑒subscript𝑁𝑒𝑒subscript𝑁𝜇𝑒italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{e}=N_{ee}+N_{\mu e} where

Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-theta CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S PUNCT:, italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-A OPEN:( italic-L PUNCT:, italic-theta CLOSE:) ARG:end INTOP:integral FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-theta CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S PUNCT:, italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-theta CLOSE:)
FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d Phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end

div.p: where R⁢(Eμ⁢0,Eμ)𝑅subscript𝐸𝜇0subscript𝐸𝜇italic-R OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)R(E_{\mu 0},E_{\mu}) is the muon range function, A⁢(L,θ)=AS⁢(Eμ,θ)+AT⁢(Eμ,θ)𝐴𝐿𝜃subscript𝐴𝑆subscript𝐸𝜇𝜃subscript𝐴𝑇subscript𝐸𝜇𝜃italic-A OPEN:( italic-L PUNCT:, italic-theta CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-theta CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-theta CLOSE:)A(L,\theta)=A_{S}(E_{\mu},\theta)+A_{T}(E_{\mu},\theta) is the projected detector area for internal pathlengths longer than L𝐿italic-LL. ASsubscript𝐴𝑆italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{S} and ATsubscript𝐴𝑇italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{T} are the corresponding areas for stopping and through-going muon trajectories.
The fitting procedure we adopt is discussed in detail in [13, 12]. Here we only recall that we define a χ2superscript𝜒2italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{2} function

semantics.annotation: italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-I PUNCT:, italic-J POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-t italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:cdot OPEN:( italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-I italic-J POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:cdot OPEN:( italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-J POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-d italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-J POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-t italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: where I𝐼italic-II and J𝐽italic-JJ stand for any combination of the experimental data sets and event-types considered. The error matrices are defined as σI⁢J2≡σα⁢(A)⁢ρα⁢β⁢(A,B)⁢σβ⁢(B)superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐼𝐽2subscript𝜎𝛼𝐴subscript𝜌𝛼𝛽𝐴𝐵subscript𝜎𝛽𝐵italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-I italic-J POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-A CLOSE:) italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-A PUNCT:, italic-B CLOSE:) italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-B CLOSE:)\sigma_{IJ}^{2}\equiv\sigma_{\alpha}(A)\,\rho_{\alpha\beta}(A,B)\,\sigma_{% \beta}(B) where ρα⁢β⁢(A,B)subscript𝜌𝛼𝛽𝐴𝐵italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-A PUNCT:, italic-B CLOSE:)\rho_{\alpha\beta}(A,B) is the correlation matrix. A detailed discussion of the errors and correlations used in our analysis can be found in Ref. [12, 13]. The final step is the minimization of the χ2superscript𝜒2italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\chi^{2} function from which we determine the allowed region in the parameter space as: χ2≡χm⁢i⁢n2+4.6,6.0,9.2superscript𝜒2superscriptsubscript𝜒𝑚𝑖𝑛24.66.09.2italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-chi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-i italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:4.6 PUNCT:, NUMBER:6.0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:9.2\chi^{2}\equiv\chi_{min}^{2}+4.6,6.0,9.2 for 90,95 and 99 % C.L.

As for the FC mechanism, we report in Table 1 the result of our fits over the different 52 kton-yrs SK data samples [1]. The same table also shows our results for the oscillation interpretation. We notice that the FC hypothesis is able to fit well all the different data sets, with statistical confidence comparable to the oscillation cases. When a global analysis is performed, the FC hypothesis turns out to be a worse explanation as compared to oscillation. This is mainly due to a too strong suppression of the horizonthal thru-going muons [11]. Nevertheless, the FC mechanism is still acceptable at 90% C.L. . Fig. 1 shows the allowed regions in the two-parameter space of the FC mechanism [11]. We can notice that, in order to describe the data, a somewhat large amount of FC in the neutrino sector is required.

As for the oscillation mechanism, we have peformed a global fit to all the available atmospheric neutrino data: Nusex [9], IMB [8], Frejus [7], Kamiokande [6], Soudan [5], Super Kamiokande [1], MACRO [3] and Baskan [4]. Some of our results are shown in Fig. 2 and in Table 2. We see that all the three oscillation channels describe the data to a good statistical level (for details, see [12]). From the results of the fit, we can conclude that, among the three possibilities, the νμ→ντ→subscript𝜈𝜇subscript𝜈𝜏italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARROW:to italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu_{\mu}\to\nu_{\tau} oscillation hypothesis turns out to be the current most favourable option.

figure.p: Table 2. Best fit results for the oscillation solution to the atmospheric neutrino problem. The analysis refers to a global fit to all the available data. In the case of the sterile channels, (-ADDOP:minus-) and (+ADDOP:plus+) stand for negative and positive Δ⁢m2Δsuperscript𝑚2Delta italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta m^{2}, respectively.

div.p: Acknowledgements. I wish to address my warmest thanks to the TAUP99 Organizers for allowing me to deliver this second talk to the Conference. This work was supported by the Spanish DGICYT under grant number PB95–1077 and by the TMR network grant ERBFMRXCT960090 of the European Union.
